sub_topic: Finding the chromatic polynomial of a graph.
message_1:
Consider a graph G shown below. 

![alt text](https://i.imgur.com/kl1Kcvp.png)

Find the chromatic polynomial of this graph G.
message_2:
To find the chromatic polynomial of the given graph G, we can use the deletion-contraction algorithm. Let P(G, k) be the chromatic polynomial of G with k colors. We will first label the vertices of the graph as follows:

![alt text](https://i.imgur.com/7Y3y1qT.png)

Now, let's apply the deletion-contraction algorithm:

1. Choose an edge to delete and contract. We will choose the edge connecting vertices A and B.
2. Delete the edge and find the chromatic polynomial of the resulting graph. This is P(G-e, k), where e is the edge we deleted.

![alt text](https://i.imgur.com/5F5Qj2Q.png)

3. Contract the edge by merging vertices A and B into a single vertex, and find the chromatic polynomial of the resulting graph. This is P(G/e, k), where e is the edge we contracted.

![alt text](https://i.imgur.com/5F5Qj2Q.png)

Now, we have two simpler graphs to find the chromatic polynomial for. Let's start with the graph G-e:

- The chromatic polynomial of G-e is P(G-e, k) = k(k-1)(k-2)(k-3).

Next, let's find the chromatic polynomial for the graph G/e:

- The chromatic polynomial of G/e is P(G/e, k) = k(k-1)(k-2).

Now, we can use the deletion-contraction formula:

P(G, k) = P(G-e, k) - P(G/e, k) = k(k-1)(k-2)(k-3) - k(k-1)(k-2).

Factor out the common term k(k-1)(k-2):

P(G, k) = k(k-1)(k-2)[(k-3) - 1] = k(k-1)(k-2)(k-4).

So, the chromatic polynomial of the given graph G is:

P(G, k) = k(k-1)(k-2)(k-4).
